verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:72
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:73
verses.text: How then, let them tell us, would they have these things to be?—a true generation, the true Son begotten of God the Father, that is, of the Substance of the Father, or of another substance? If they say "begotten of the Father, that is, of the Substance of God," well and good, for then they acknowledge the Son as begotten of the Substance of the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:74
verses.text: If, then, they are of one Substance, surely they are also of one sovereign Power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:75
verses.text: Whereas, if the Son is begotten of another substance, how can the Father be Almighty, and the Son not Almighty? For what advantage hath God, if He have made His Son of another substance, when confessedly the Son, on His part, hath of another substance made us sons of God? The Son, therefore, is either of one Substance with the Father, or of one sovereign Power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:76
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:77
verses.text: Our adversaries' question, then, falls flat, because they cannot judge Christ—or rather, because He is clear, when He is judged.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:78
verses.text: They are worthy, however, to be condemned upon their own sentence, who raise this question against us, for if the Son be therefore not equal to the Father, because He hath not begotten a Son, then by all means let them who sow discussions of this kind confess, if they have not children, that their very servants are to be preferred before themselves, inasmuch as they cannot be the equals of those who have children—whereas, if they have children, let them regard the merit thereof as due not to themselves, but of right to their sons.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:79
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 8:80
verses.text: The objection, then, holds not together, that the Son cannot be equal to the Father, by reason of the Father having begotten the Son, whilst the Son has begotten no Son of Himself, for the spring begets the stream, though the stream begets no spring out of itself, and light begets radiance, and not radiance light, yet the nature of radiance and light is one.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:2
verses.text: Various quibbling arguments, advanced by the Arians to show that the Son had a beginning of existence, are considered and refuted, on the ground that whilst the Arians plainly prove nothing, or if they prove anything, prove it against themselves, (inasmuch as He Who is the beginning of all cannot Himself have a beginning), their reasonings do not even hold true with regard to facts of human existence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:3
verses.text: Time could not be before He was, Who is the Author of time—if indeed at some time He was not in existence, then the Father was without His Power and Wisdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:4
verses.text: Again, our own human experience shows that a person is said to exist before he is born.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:6
verses.text: Now that our opponents have failed to maintain their objection against the truth of  His Son's equality with the Father, on the ground of His Generation, let them see that their well known device of controversy, their stock misrepresentation, is frustrated.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:7
verses.text: Their common use is to propound this riddle: "How can the Son be equal with the Father? If He is a Son, then before He was begotten He was not in existence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:8
verses.text: If He was in existence, why was He begotten?" And men who advance difficulties raised by Arius yet sturdily deny that they are Arians.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:10
verses.text: Accordingly, they demand our answer, intending, if we say, "The Son existed before He was begotten," to meet us with a subtle retort, that "If so, then, before He was begotten, He was created, and there is no difference between Him and the rest of created beings, for He began to be a creature before He began to be the Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:11
verses.text: To which they add: "Why was He begotten, when He was already in existence? Because He was imperfect, and in order that He might afterwards be made more perfect?" Whilst if we reply that the Son did not exist before He was begotten, they will immediately reply: "Then by being begotten He was brought into existence, not having existed before He was begotten," so as to lead on from this to the conclusion that "the Son existed, when He did not exist".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:12
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:13
verses.text: But let those who propound this difficulty and endeavour to enwrap the truth in a cloud tell us themselves whether the Father exerts His power of begetting within or without limits of time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:14
verses.text: If they say "within limits of time," then they will attribute to the Father what they object against the Son, so as to make the Father seem to have begun to be what He was not before.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:15
verses.text: If their answer is "without such limits," then what is left them but to resolve for themselves the problem they have propounded, and acknowledge that the Son is not begotten under limits and conditions of time, since they deny that the Father so begets?  100.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:16
verses.text: If the Son, then, is not begotten within limits of time, we are free to judge that nothing can have existed before the Son, Whose being is not confined by time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:17
verses.text: If, indeed, there was anything in being before the Son, then it instantly follows that in Him were not created all things in heaven or in earth, and the Apostle is shown to have erred in so setting it down in his Epistle, whereas, if before He was begotten there was nothing, I see not wherefore He, before Whom none was, should be said to have been after any.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:19
verses.text: With the consideration whereof we must join another most blasphemous objection of theirs, which covers a subtle purpose to confuse the sense and understanding of simple folk.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:20
verses.text: They ask whether everything that comes to an end had also at any time a beginning.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:21
verses.text: If they are told that what has an end also had a beginning, then they return to the charge with the question whether the Father has ceased to beget His Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:22
verses.text: This by our consent being granted them, they conclude that the generation of the Son had a beginning.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:23
verses.text: The which if you allow, it seems to follow that if the Generation had a beginning, it appears to have begun in Him Who was begotten; so that one, who had not existed before, may be called "begotten"—their intent being to close the inquiry by laying down as conclusive that there was a time when the Son existed not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:24
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:25
verses.text: Besides this, there are other vain objections, such as persons of their glibness of tongue would readily urge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:26
verses.text: If, say they, the Son is the Word of the Father, then He is called "begotten," inasmuch as He is the Word.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:27
verses.text: But then since He is the Word, He is not a work.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:28
verses.text: Now the Father has spoken "in divers manners," whence it follows that He has begotten many Sons, if He has spoken His Word, not created it as a work of His hands.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:29
verses.text: O fools, talking as though they knew not the difference between the word uttered and the Divine Word, abiding eternally, born of the Father—born, I say, not uttered only—in Whom is no combination of syllables, but the fulness of the eternal Godhead and life without end!  103.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:30
verses.text: Follows another blasphemy, whereby they enquire whether it was of His own free will, or on compulsion, that the Father begat [His Son], intending, if we say, "Of His own free will," that we should appear as though we acknowledged that the Father's Will preceded the [Divine] Generation, and to answer that there being something that preceded the existence of the Son, the Son is not co-eternal with the Father, or that He, like the rest of the world, is a being created, forasmuch as it is written, "He hath made all things, as many as He would," though this is spoken, not of the Father and  the Son, but of those creatures which the Son made.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:31
verses.text: Whereas if we answered that the Father begat [His Son] on compulsion, we should seem to have attributed infirmity to the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:32
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:33
verses.text: But in the eternal Generation there is no foregoing condition, neither of will, nor of unwillingness, and therefore I can neither say that the Father begat of His free Will, nor yet that He begat on compulsion, for to beget depends not upon possibility as determined by will, but rather appears to stand in a certain right and property of the hidden being of the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:34
verses.text: For just as the Father is not good because He wills to be so, or is compelled to be so, but is above these conditions—is good, that is, by nature,—even so the putting forth of His generative power is neither of will nor of necessity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:35
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:36
verses.text: Yet let us grant their proposal.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:37
verses.text: Granted that the Generation depends on the Will of Him Who generates; when do they say that this act of will took place? If it was in the beginning, then, plainly, the Son was in the beginning.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:38
verses.text: If the Will is eternal, then the Son also is eternal.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:39
verses.text: If the Will began to exist, then God the Father, as He was, was so displeased with Himself, that He made a change in His condition, that is to say, without His Son He was displeasing to Himself; in His Son He began to be well pleased.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:40
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:41
verses.text: To follow out the consequences thereof.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:42
verses.text: If the Father conceived, after the manner of human nature, a desire to beget, then did He also pass through all the experiences which befal men before the birth takes place—but we find that generation is not determined merely by will, but is an object of wish.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:43
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:44
verses.text: Thus do they betray their own ungodliness, who would have it that Christ's generation had a beginning, in order that it may seem, not that true begetting of the Word abiding, but the utterance of words that pass and are forgotten, and that by intrusion of [the premiss of] a multitude of sons, they may [be warranted to] deny Christ's personal possession of the divine attributes, to the end that He may be regarded as neither the only-begotten nor the first-begotten Son; and lastly, that given the belief that His existence had a beginning, it may also be deemed as appointed to have an end.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:45
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:46
verses.text: But neither had the Son of God any beginning, seeing that He already was at the beginning, nor shall He come to an end, Who is the Beginning and the End of the Universe; for being the Beginning, how could He take and receive that which He already had, or how shall He come to an end, being Himself the End of all things, so that in that End we have an abiding-place without end? The Divine Generation is not an event occurring in the course of time, and within its limits, and therefore before it time is not, and in it time has no place.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:47
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:48
verses.text: Again, their aimless and futile question finds no loophole for entry, even when directed upon the creation itself; nay, indeed, temporal existences appear, in certain cases, to admit of no division of time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:49
verses.text: For instance, light generates radiance, but we can neither conceive that the radiance begins to exist after the light, nor that the light is in existence before the radiance, for where there is a light, there is radiance, and where there is radiance there is also a light; and thus we can neither have a light without radiance, nor radiance without light, because both the light is in the radiance, and the radiance in the light.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:50
verses.text: Thus the Apostle was taught to call the Son "the Radiance of the Father's Glory," for the Son is the Radiance of His Father's light, co-eternal, because of eternity of Power; inseparable, by unity of brightness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:51
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:52
verses.text: If then we can neither understand the mystery of, nor dissociate, these created objects in the sky above us, which we see, can we comprehend Him Whom we see not, Who is above every created existence, God, as He is in the very Holy of Holies of His own Generation? Can we make time a barrier between Him and the Son, when all time is the creation of the Son?  111.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:53
verses.text: Let them cease therefore, and say no more that before He was begotten the Son was not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:54
verses.text: For the word "before" is a mark of time, whereas the Generation is before  all times, and therefore that which comes after aught comes not before it, and the work cannot be before the maker, seeing that necessarily objects made take their commencement from the craftsman who makes them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:55
verses.text: How can the customary action of any created object be regarded as existing prior to the maker of it, whilst all time is a creation, and every creation has taken its being from its creator?  112.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:56
verses.text: I would, therefore, further examine our opponents, who esteem themselves so cunning, and have them make good the application of their theory to human existence, seeing that they use it to disparage the glory of God's Existence, and keep far away from any confession of an inscrutable mystery in the Divine Generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:57
verses.text: I would have them find ground for their objection in the facts of human generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:58
verses.text: Of God's Son they assert that before He was begotten He was not,—that is to say, they say this of the Wisdom, the Power, the Word of God, Whose Generation knows nothing prior to itself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:59
verses.text: But if, as they would have us believe, there was a time when the Son existed not (the which it is blasphemy to affirm), then there was a time when God lacked the fulness of Divine Perfection, if afterwards He passed through a process of begetting a Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:60
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:61
verses.text: To show them, however, the weakness and transparency of their objection, though it has no real relation to any truth, divine or human, I will prove to them that men have existed before they were born.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:62
verses.text: Else, let them show that Jacob, who whilst yet hidden in the secret chamber of his mother's womb supplanted his brother, had not been appointed and ordained, ere ever he was born; let them show that Jeremiah had not likewise been so, before his birth,—Jeremiah, to whom the message comes: "Before I formed thee in thy mother's womb, I knew thee; and before thou camest forth from the belly, I sanctified thee, and appointed thee for a prophet amongst the nations".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:63
verses.text: What testimony can we have stronger than the case of this great prophet, who was sanctified before he was born, and known before he was shaped?  114.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:64
verses.text: What, again, shall I say of John, of whom his holy mother testifies that, whilst he yet lay in her womb, he perceived in spirit the presence of his Lord, and leaped for joy, as we remember it to be written, his mother saying: "For lo, as soon as the voice of the salutation entered mine ears, the babe leaped in my womb for joy".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:65
verses.text: Was he, then, who prophesied, in existence or not? Nay, surely he was—surely he was in being who worshipped his Maker; he was in being who spake in his mother's womb.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:66
verses.text: And so Elisabeth was filled with the spirit of her son, and Mary sanctified by the Spirit of hers, for thus you may find it recorded, that "the babe leaped in her womb, and Elisabeth was filled with the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:67
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:68
verses.text: Consider the proper force of each word.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:69
verses.text: Elisabeth was indeed the first to hear the voice of Mary, but John was first to feel His Lord's gracious Presence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:70
verses.text: Sweet is the harmony of prophecy with prophecy, of woman with woman, of babe with babe.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:71
verses.text: The women speak words of grace, the babes move hiddenly, and as their mothers approach one another, so do they engage in mysterious converse of love; and in a twofold miracle, though in diverse degrees of honour, the mothers prophesy in the spirit of their little ones.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:72
verses.text: Who, I ask, was it that performed this miracle? Was it not the Son of God, Who made the unborn to be?  116.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 9:73
verses.text: Thus your objection fails of reconcilement with the truths of human existence—can it attain thereto with divine mysteries? What mean you by your principle that "before He was begotten He was not"? Was the Father engaged for some time in conception, so that certain epochs passed away before the Son was begotten? Was He, like women, in travail of birth, so that just this travail? What would you? Why seek we to pry into divine mysteries? The Scriptures tell me the necessary effects of the Divine Generation, not how it is done.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:2
verses.text: The objection that Christ, on the showing of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:3
verses.text: John, lives because of the Father, and therefore is not to be regarded as equal with the Father, is met by the reply that for the Life of the Son, in respect of His Godhead, there has never been a time when it began; and that it is dependent upon none, whilst the passage in question must be understood as referring to His human life, as is shown by His speaking there of His body and blood.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:4
verses.text: Two expositions of the passage are given, the one of which is shown to refer to Christ's Manhood, whilst the second teaches His equality with the Father, as also His likeness with men.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:5
verses.text: Rebuke is administered to the Arians for the insult which they are seeking to inflict upon the Son, and the sense in which the Son can be said to live "because of" the Father is explained, as also the union of life with the divine Life.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:6
verses.text: A further objection, based upon the Son's prayer that He may be glorified by the Father, is briefly refuted.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:7
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:8
verses.text: There are not a few who raise this further objection, that it is written: "As the living Father hath sent Me, and I live by the Father; so he that eateth Me, liveth also by Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:9
verses.text: "How," ask they, "is the Son equal with the Father, when He has said that He lives by the Father?"  119.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:10
verses.text: Let those who oppose us on this ground tell us first what the Life of the Son is.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:11
verses.text: Is it a life bestowed by the Father upon one lacking life? But how could the Son ever fail to possess life, He Himself being the Life, as He says, "I am the Way, the Truth, and the Life".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:12
verses.text: Truly, His life is eternal, even as His power is eternal.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:13
verses.text: Was there a time, then, when (so to speak) Life possessed not itself?  120.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:14
verses.text: Bethink you what is read this day concerning the Lord Jesus, that "He died for our sakes, to the end that whether we wake or whether we sleep, we may live with Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:15
verses.text: He Whose Death is Life, is not His Godhead Life, seeing that the Godhead is Life eternal?  121.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:16
verses.text: But is His Life truly in the Father's power? Why, He showed that even His bodily life was not in the power of any other, as we have it on record: "I lay down My life, that I may take it again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:17
verses.text: No man taketh it from Me, but I lay it down of Myself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:18
verses.text: I have power to lay it down, and again I have power to take it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:19
verses.text: This commandment have I received of My Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:20
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:21
verses.text: Is His divine Life then to be regarded as depending upon the power of another, when His bodily life was subject to no other power but His own? For it would have been the power of another, but for the Unity of power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:22
verses.text: But just as He gives us to understand that His laying down His life was done of His own power, and of His free Will, so also He teaches us, in laying it down in obedience to His Father's command, the unity of His own with the Father's Will.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:24
verses.text: If, then, there has neither been a time when the Life of the Son took a commencement, nor any power to which it has been subjected, let us consider what His meaning was when He said: "Even as the living Father hath sent Me, and I live by the Father"? Let us expound His meaning as best we can; nay, rather let Him expound it Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:26
verses.text: Take notice, then, what He said in an earlier part of His discourse.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:27
verses.text: "Verily, verily, I say unto you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:28
verses.text: He first teaches thee how thou oughtest to listen.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:29
verses.text: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, unless ye eat the flesh of the Son of Man, and drink His blood, ye shall have no life in you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:30
verses.text: He first premised that He was speaking as Son of Man; dost thou then think that what He hath said, as Son of Man, concerning His Flesh and His Blood, is to be applied to His Godhead?  125.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:31
verses.text: Then He added: "For My Flesh is meat indeed, and My Blood is drink [indeed]".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:32
verses.text: Thou hearest Him speak of His Flesh and of His Blood, thou perceivest the sacred pledges, [conveying to us the merits and power] of the Lord's death, and thou dishonourest His Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:33
verses.text: Hear His own words: "A spirit hath not flesh and bones".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:34
verses.text: Now we, as often as we receive the Sacramental Elements, which by the mysterious efficacy of holy prayer are transformed into the Flesh and the Blood, "do show the Lord's Death".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:35
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:36
verses.text: Then, after calling on us to take notice that He speaks as Son of Man, and frequent repeated mention of His Flesh and His Blood, He adds: "Even as the living Father hath sent Me, and I live by the Father, so he that eateth Me, he also liveth by Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:37
verses.text: How then do they suppose that we are to understand these words?—for the comparison can be shown as a double one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:38
verses.text: The first comparison being after the following manner: "Even as the living Father hath sent Me, I live by the Father;" the second: "Even as the living Father hath sent Me, and I live by the Father, so also he that eateth Me, he too liveth by Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:39
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:40
verses.text: If our adversaries choose the former, the meaning is this, that, "as I am sent by the Father and am come down from the Father, so (in accordance therewith) I live by the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:41
verses.text: But in what character was He sent, and came down, save as Son of Man, even as He Himself said before: "No man hath ascended into heaven, save He that hath come down from heaven as Son of Man".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:42
verses.text: Then, just as He was sent and came down as Son of Man, so as Son of Man He lives by the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:43
verses.text: Furthermore, he that eateth Him, as eating the Son of Man, doth himself also live by the Son of Man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:44
verses.text: Thus, He has compared the effect of His Incarnation to His coming.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:45
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:46
verses.text: But if they choose the second method, do we not infer both the equality of the Son with the Father, and His likeness to men, together, though in clear mutual distinction? For what is the meaning of the words, "Even as He Himself liveth by the Father, so we also live by Him," but that the Son so quickeneth a man, as the Father hath in the Son quickened human nature? "For as the Father raiseth the dead and quickeneth them, so also the Son quickeneth whom He will," as the Lord Himself hath already said.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:47
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:48
verses.text: Thus the equality of the Son to the Father is established simply upon unity in the action of quickening, since the Son so quickeneth as the Father doth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:49
verses.text: Acknowledge therefore the eternity of His Life and Sovereignty.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:50
verses.text: Again, our likeness with the Son is discovered, and a certain unity with Him in the flesh, because that, like as the Son of God was quickened in the flesh by the Father, so also is man quickened; for thus it is written, that as God raised Jesus Christ from the dead, so we also, as men, are quickened by the Son of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:51
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:52
verses.text: According to this interpretation, then, immortality is not only applied to our condition by grace of bounty, but is also proclaimed as the property of Godhead—the latter, because it is the Godhead which quickeneth; the former, because manhood is quickened in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:53
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:54
verses.text: But if any would apply the force of either comparison to Christ's Godhead, then the Son of God is put on one footing with men, so that the Son of God lives by the Father just as we live by the Son of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:55
verses.text: But the Son of God bestows eternal life by free gift, we cannot so do.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:56
verses.text: If then He be placed on a level with us, He too does not bestow this gift.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:57
verses.text: Let Arius' disciples then have the due reward of their faith—which is, not to obtain eternal life of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:58
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:59
verses.text: I would now go further.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:60
verses.text: If our opponents are pleased to apply the teaching of this passage to the principle of the eternity of the Divine Substance, let them hear a third exposition: Does not our Lord plainly appear to say that as the Father is a living Father, so too the Son also lives?—and who can but observe that here we must understand a reference to unity of Life, forasmuch as the same Life is the Life of the Father and the Life of the Son? "For as the Father hath Life in Himself, so hath He given to the Son also to have Life in Himself".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:61
verses.text: He hath given—by reason of unity with Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:62
verses.text: He hath given, not to take away, but that He may be glorified in the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:63
verses.text: He hath given, not that He, the Father, might keep guard over it, but that the Son might have it in possession.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:64
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:65
verses.text: But the Arians think that they must oppose hereto the fact that He had said, "I live by the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:66
verses.text: Of a certainty (suppose that they conceive the words as referring to His Godhead) the Son lives by the Father, because He is the Son begotten of the Father,—by the Father, because He is of one Substance with the Father,—by the Father, because He is the Word given forth from the heart of the Father, because He came forth from the Father, because He is begotten of the "bowels of the Father," because the Father is the Fountain and Root of the Son's being.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:67
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:68
verses.text: But peradventure they may urge: "If you hold that the Son, in saying, 'And I live by the Father,' spoke of the unity of life subsisting between the Father and the Son, does it not follow that He discovered the unity of life between the Son and mankind in saying that 'he that eateth Me, the same liveth by Me'?"  135.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:69
verses.text: Even so.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:70
verses.text: Just as I confess the unity of celestial Life subsisting in Father and Son by reason of the unity of the substance of the Godhead, so too, save as concerns the prerogatives of the Divine Nature or those which are the effect of the Incarnation of our Lord, I affirm of the Son a participation of spiritual life with us by virtue of the unity of His Manhood with ours, for "as is the heavenly, such are they also that are heavenly".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:71
verses.text: Further, even as in Him we sit at the right hand of the Father, not in the sense that we share His throne, but that we rest in the Body of Christ—even as, I say, we have part in Christ's session by reason of corporal unity, so too we live  in Christ by reason of unity of our bodies with His Body.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:72
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:73
verses.text: Not only, then, have I no fears of the text, "I live by the Father," but I should have none, even though Christ had said, "I live by help of the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:74
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:75
verses.text: Now another objection commonly urged by them starts from the text: "This sickness is not unto death, but for the glory of God, to the end that His Son may be glorified by Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:76
verses.text: But not only is the Son glorified through the Father and by the Father, as it is written: "Glorify Me, Father;" and again: "Now hath the Son of Man been glorified, and God hath been glorified in Him, and God glorifieth Him," but the Father also is glorified through the Son and by the Son, for Truth hath said: "I have glorified Thee upon earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:77
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:78
verses.text: Even as the Son, therefore, is glorified through the Father, so too He lives by the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 10:79
verses.text: There are some who have been led by consideration of these words to the supposition that [the Greek] "δόξα" means "opinion, belief," rather than "glory," and therefore have interpreted as follows: "I have given thee a δόξα upon earth, I have finished the work which Thou gavest Me to do, and now, O Father, give me a δόξα;" that is to say: "I have taught men so to believe concerning Thee, as to know that Thou art the true God; do Thou also establish in them, concerning Me, the belief that I am Thy Son, and very God".

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:2
verses.text: The particular distinction which the Arians endeavoured to prove upon the Apostle's teaching that all things are "of" the Father and "through" the Son, is overthrown, it being shown that in the passage cited the same Omnipotence is ascribed both to Father and to Son, as is proved from various texts, especially from the words of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:3
verses.text: Paul himself, in which heretics foolishly find a reference to the Father only, though indeed there is no diminution or inferiority of the Son's sovereignty proved, even by such a reference.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:4
verses.text: Finally, the three phrases, "of Whom," "through Whom," "in Whom," are shown to suppose or imply no difference (of power), and each and all to hold true of the Three Persons.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:6
verses.text: Now we come to that laughable method, attempted by some, of showing a difference of Power to subsist between Father and Son, on the strength of apostolic testimony, it being written: "But for us there is One God, the Father, of Whom are all things, and we in Him, and One Lord, Jesus Christ, through Whom are all things, and we through Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:7
verses.text: It is urged that no small difference in degree of Divine Majesty is signified in the affirmation that all things are "of" the Father, and "through" the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:8
verses.text: Whereas nothing is clearer than that here a plain reason is given of the Omnipotence of the Son, inasmuch as whilst all things are "of" the Father, none the less are they all "through" the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:10
verses.text: The Father is not "amongst" all things, for to Him it is confessed that "all things serve Thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:11
verses.text: Nor is the Son reckoned "amongst" all things, for "all things were made by Him," and "all things exist together in Him, and He is above all the heavens".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:12
verses.text: The Son, therefore, exists not "amongst" but above all things, being, indeed, after the flesh, of the people, of the Jews, but yet at the same time God over all, blessed for ever, having a Name which is above every name, it being said of Him, "Thou hast put all things in subjection under His feet".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:13
verses.text: But in making all things subject to Him, He left nothing that is not subject, even as the Apostle hath said.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:14
verses.text: But suppose that the Apostle's words were intended with reference to the Incarnate Lord; how then can we doubt the incomparable majesty of His Divine Generation?  141.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:15
verses.text: Certain it is, then, that between Father and Son there can be no difference of Power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:16
verses.text: Nay, so far is such difference from being present, that the same Apostle has said that all things are "of" Him, by Whom are all things, as followeth: "For of Him and through Him and in Him are all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:18
verses.text: Now if, as they suppose, it is the Father alone Who is spoken of, it cannot be that He is at once Omnipotent because all things are of Him, and not Omnipotent because all things are through Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:19
verses.text: On  their own showing, then, they will declare the Father lacking in Power, and not Omnipotent, or at the least they will be confessing with their own mouth, all against their will though it be, the Omnipotence of the Son as well as of the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:20
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:21
verses.text: Howbeit, let them decide whether they will understand this affirmation as made concerning the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:22
verses.text: If they do so decide then all things are "through" Him also.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:23
verses.text: If they decide that it is the Son Who is spoken of, then all things are "of" Him as well as "of" the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:24
verses.text: But if all things are "through" the Father also, then surely there is no argument for diminishing from the honour due to the Son; and if all things are "of" the Son, the Son must be honoured in like manner as the Father is.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:26
verses.text: In case our opponents should suspect that we are taking advantage of some intrusion of a single spurious verse into the text, let us review the whole passage.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:27
verses.text: "O depth of the riches of God's wisdom and knowledge!" exclaims the Apostle, "how unsearchable are His judgments, and His ways past finding out! For Who hath known the mind of the Lord, or who hath been His counsellor? Or who hath been first to give unto Him, and shall be recompensed? For of Him and through Him and in Him are all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:28
verses.text: To Him be glory for ever!"  145.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:29
verses.text: Who, then, think they, is here spoken of—the Father or the Son? If it be the Father—then we answer that the Father is not the Wisdom of God, for the Son is.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:30
verses.text: But what is there that is impossible to Wisdom, of Whom it is written: "Seeing that she is almighty and abiding, she maketh all things new in herself"? We read of Wisdom, then, not as approaching, but as abiding.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:31
verses.text: Thus have you the authority of Solomon to teach you of the Omnipotence and Eternity of Wisdom, and of her Goodness as well, for it is written: "But malice overcometh not Wisdom".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:32
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:33
verses.text: But to purpose.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:34
verses.text: "How unsearchable," saith the Apostle, "are His judgments!" Now if "the Father hath given all judgment to the Son," it seems that the Father points to the Son as Judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:35
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:36
verses.text: But now, to show us that He is speaking of the Son, not of the Father, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:37
verses.text: Paul proceeds: "Who was first in giving to Him?" For "the Father hath given to the Son," but it was as acknowledging the rights of Him Whom He has begotten, not by way of largess.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:38
verses.text: Therefore, it being undeniable that the Son has received at the hands of the Father, as it is written, "All things have been given unto Me of My Father," yet, in saying, "Who was first in giving to Him?" the Apostle has not denied that the Son has received gifts of the Father, by virtue of His Nature, but he has indeed shown that, of Father and Son, Neither can be said to be before the Other, forasmuch as, albeit the Father has given gifts unto the Son, yet He has not so bestowed them as upon one that began to be after Him; because the uncreate and incomprehensible Trinity, Which is of One Eternity and Glory, admits neither difference of time nor degree of precedence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:39
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:40
verses.text: If, however, we hold ourselves more bound to observe those Greek manuscripts which show "τίς προσέδωχεν αὐτῳ;" it is clear that He to Whom nothing can be added is not unequal to Him Who is perfect and complete.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:41
verses.text: Therefore, if this passage from the Apostle, in its entirety, is better understood with reference to the Son, we see that we must also believe concerning the Son, that all things are of Him, even as it is written: "For of Him and through Him and in Him are all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:42
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:43
verses.text: Be it so, nevertheless, that they suppose the passage to be intended of the Father, then let us call to mind that even as we read of all things being of Him, so too we read of all things being through Him, that is to say, the authority of the Father and of the Son is extended over the whole created universe.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:44
verses.text: And, though we have already proved the Omnipotence of the Son by the Omnipotence of the Father, still—forasmuch as they are ever bent upon disparagement—let them consider that they disparage the Father as well as the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:45
verses.text: For if the Son be limited in might, because all things are through Him, do we say further, that the Father likewise is limited, because all things are through Him also?  150.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:46
verses.text: But to bring them to understand that  these phrases involve no difference, I will once again show that it is the same person, "of" whom anything is, and "through" whom anything is, and that we read of things being related in both these ways to the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:47
verses.text: For we find: "Faithful is God, through Whom ye were called into the fellowship of His Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:48
verses.text: Let our adversaries weigh the meaning of the Apostle's words.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:49
verses.text: We are called "through" the Father—they raise no controversy: we are created "through" the Son—and this they have set down as a mark of inferiority.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:50
verses.text: The Father has called us into fellowship with His Son, and this truth we, as in duty bound, devoutly receive.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:51
verses.text: The Son has created all things, and Arius' followers imagine that here they have not the decree of a free Will, but a forced service, slavishly performed!  151.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:52
verses.text: Again, to obtain fuller understanding that, forasmuch as we are called through the Father into fellowship with His Son, there is no difference of Power in the Father and the Son, [note that] the fellowship itself has its beginning of the Son, as it is written: "For from His fulness have we all received," though, if we follow the Greek text of the Gospel, we ought to render "of His fulness".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:53
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:54
verses.text: See, then, how there is fellowship both through the Father and of the Son, and yet not a different fellowship, but one and the same.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:55
verses.text: "And that our fellowship be with the Father and with His Son Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:56
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:57
verses.text: Observe, further, that Scripture speaks of our having one fellowship not only "of" the Father and the Son, but also "of" the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:58
verses.text: "The grace of Our Lord Jesus Christ," saith the Apostle, "and the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit be with you all".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:59
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:60
verses.text: Now, I ask, wherein does He, through Whom are all things, appear less than He, of Whom are all things? Is it because He is declared to be the Worker? But the Father also works, for He is true who said, "My Father worketh hitherto, and I work".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:61
verses.text: Therefore, even as the Father worketh, so worketh the Son also; and so He Who worketh is not limitary in power nor abject, for the Father also worketh; which being so, that which is common to the Son with the Father, or even which the Son has by the Father, ought not to be the less esteemed, lest heretics further dishonour the Father in the Person of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:62
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:63
verses.text: Not to be passed over for silencing the disputings of Arian misbelief are those words of the same Saint John, which he set down in another Scripture: "If ye know that He is just, know that he which doeth righteousness is born of Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:64
verses.text: But who is righteous, save the Lord, Who loveth righteousness? Or whom—as the foregoing texts warn us—have we to assure us of everlasting life, if we have not the Son? If, therefore, the Son of God hath promised us everlasting life, and He is righteous, surely we are born "of" Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:65
verses.text: Else, if our adversaries deny that we are born of the Son by grace, they likewise deny His righteousness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:66
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:67
verses.text: Thou must therefore believe that all things are of the Son of God [even as of God the Father, for even as God is the Father of all, so likewise is the Son the Author and Creator of all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:68
verses.text: We see, then, the vanity of this their questioning, forasmuch as it holds good of the Son [as of the Father], that "of Him and through Him and in Him are all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:69
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:70
verses.text: We have shown how all things are "of" Him, and likewise how all things are also "through" Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:71
verses.text: Who then doubts that all things are "in" Him, when another Scripture saith: "For in Him are all things founded, that are in the heavens, and in Him they were created, and He is before all things, and all things consist in Him"? (Col.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:72
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:73
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 11:74
verses.text: Of Him, then, thou hast grace; Himself thou hast for thy Creator; in Him thou findest the foundation of all things.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:2
verses.text: The comparison, found in the Gospel of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:3
verses.text: John, of the Son to a Vine and the Father to a husbandman, must be understood with reference to the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:4
verses.text: To understand it with reference to the Divine Generation is to doubly insult the Son, making Him inferior to St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:5
verses.text: Paul, and bringing Him down to the level of the rest of mankind, as well as in like manner the Father also, by making Him not merely to be on one footing with the same Apostle, but even of no account at all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:6
verses.text: The Son, indeed, in so far as being God, is also the husbandman, and, as regards His Manhood, a grape-cluster.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:7
verses.text: True statement of the Father's pre-eminence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:8
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:9
verses.text: There is yet another Scripture, which our opponents commonly object against us, in order to prove their division of the Godhead of the Father from the Godhead of the  Son, namely, our Lord's words in the Gospel: "I am the true Vine and My Father is the Husbandman".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:10
verses.text: The vine and the husbandman, say they, are of different natures, and the vine is in the power of the husbandman.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:12
verses.text: Thus, then, ye would have us believe that the Son, as touching His Godhead, is like to a vine, so that without a vine-dresser He is nothing, and may be neglected or even rooted up.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:13
verses.text: Thus ye juggle up a lie from the letter of the Scripture which sayeth that our Lord called Himself the Vine, intending thereby the mystery of His Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:14
verses.text: Howbeit, if ye are bent on it that we dispute upon the letter, I too confess, yea, I proclaim, that the Son called Himself the Vine.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:15
verses.text: For woe be to me, if I deny the pledge of the salvation of His people!  160.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:16
verses.text: How then do you purpose to understand the truth that the Son of God called Himself the Vine? If you interpret the saying with respect to the Substance of His Godhead, and if you suppose such a diversity of Godhead between the Father and the Son as there is of nature between a husbandman and a vine, you do double insult both to Father and to Son—to the Son, because if, as you affirm, He is, as touching His Godhead, beneath a husbandman, then must He on the same showing be esteemed lower than the Apostle Paul, forasmuch as Paul indeed called himself a husbandman, as we find it written: "I have planted, Apollos hath watered: but God hath given the increase".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:17
verses.text: Will you have Paul, then, to be better than the Son of God?  161.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:18
verses.text: Thus far the one insult.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:19
verses.text: As for the other, it lies herein, that if the Son is the Vine in respect of His eternally-begotten Person, then, He having said: "I am the Vine, ye are the branches," that divinely-begotten One appears to be of one substance with us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:20
verses.text: But "who is like unto Thee among the gods, O Lord?" as it is written; and again, in the Psalms: "For who is there among the clouds that shall be equal to the Lord? Or who among the sons of God shall be like unto God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:21
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:22
verses.text: Moreover, ye disparage not only the Son, but the Father also.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:23
verses.text: For if the term "husbandman" is to comprehend in its designation all the prerogative of the Father's Sovereignty, then, seeing that Paul too is a husbandman, you set the Apostle, to whom you deny that the Son is equal, on an even footing with the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:24
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:25
verses.text: Again, it being written, "But neither he which planteth is anything, nor he that watereth; but God, Who giveth the increase," you will rest the fulness of the Father's Majesty in a name which, as you see, stands for weakness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:26
verses.text: For if he that planteth is nothing, and he that watereth is nothing, but it is God, Who giveth the increase [Who is all], observe what your blasphemy intends—even to expose the Father to contempt under the title of a husbandman, and to demand another God to provide the increase of the Father's labour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:27
verses.text: Wickedly, therefore, do they think to extol the Dignity of God the Father by this use of the term "husbandman," in which God the Father is brought down to the level of man, as being designated by a common title.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:28
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:29
verses.text: Yet what wonder if, as ye heretics would have it, the Father is to be exalted above a Son Whose Godhead differs not a whit from the common condition of mankind? If ye suppose the Son to have been entitled the Vine with respect to His Godhead, then do ye esteem Him not only as liable to corruption and subject to changes of wind and weather, but even as partaking of manhood only, forasmuch as the Vine and its branches are of one nature, so that the Son of God appears, not to have taken upon Him our flesh, through the mystery of Incarnation, but to have altogether sprung into being from the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:30
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:31
verses.text: But I will indeed openly confess that His flesh, though born in a new and mysterious birth, was yet of the same nature with ours, and that this is the pledge of our salvation, not the source of the Divine Generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:32
verses.text: He indeed is the Vine, for He bears my sufferings, whensoever manhood, hitherto frail, leans on Him and so matures with plenteous fruit of renewed devotion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:33
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:34
verses.text: Yet if the husbandman's power allure thee, tell me, prithee, who it was that spake in the prophet, saying: "O Lord, make it known to me, that I may know; then saw I their thoughts.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:35
verses.text: I was led as a harmless lamb to the slaughter and knew it not: they took counsel together against me, saying, Come, let us throw wood into his bread".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:36
verses.text: For if the Son here speaks of the mystery of His coming Incarnation—for it were blasphemy to suppose that the words are spoken concerning the Father—then surely it is the Son Who speaks in an earlier passage: "I have planted thee as a fruitful vine—how art Thou become bitter, and a wild vine?"  167.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:37
verses.text: And thus thou seest that the Son also is the husbandman,—the Son, of one Name with the Father, one work, one dignity and Substance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:38
verses.text: If, then, the Son is both Vine and Husbandman, plainly we infer the meaning of the Vine with regard to the mystery of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:39
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:40
verses.text: But not only has our Lord called Himself a Vine—He has also given Himself, by the voice of the prophet, the title of a Grape-cluster—even when Moses, at the command of the Lord, sent spies to the Valley of the Cluster.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:41
verses.text: What is that valley but the humility of the Incarnation and the fruitfulness of the Passion? I indeed think that He is called the Cluster, because that from the Vine brought out of Egypt, that is, the people of the Jews, there grew a fruit for the world's good.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:42
verses.text: No man, truly, can understand the Cluster as a token of the Divine Generation—or if there be any who so understand it, they leave no conclusion open but that we should believe that Cluster to have sprung from the Vine.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:43
verses.text: And thus in their folly they attribute to the Father that which they refuse to believe of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:44
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:45
verses.text: But if there be now left no room for doubt that the Son of God is called the Vine with respect and intention to His Incarnation, you see what hidden truth it was to which our Lord had regard in saying, "The Father is greater than I".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:46
verses.text: For after this premised, He proceeded immediately: "I am the true Vine, and My Father is the Husbandman," that you might know that the Father is greater in so far as He dresses and tends our Lord's flesh, as the husbandman dresses and tends his vines.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book IV 12:47
verses.text: Further, our Lord's flesh is that which could increase in stature with age, and be wounded through suffering, to the end that the whole human race might rest guarded from the pestilent heat of the pleasures of this world, under the shadow of the Cross whereon Its limbs are spread.
